title: How did the Soviet Union justify paying different wages to different workers? Aren’t people all equal in the work place? - Quora

response.answer_text: I want to note a wonderful answer and quote Hersh Bortman "There is no such thing in the nature of people like all the equal in the work-place." It is worth noting that in the USSR labor for the benefit of society was in the first place. Since childhood, children have been taught to respect work and do what they like with great desire and skill. I tried to add a few posters of the times of the USSR to feel the time of the USSR  Poster of the USSR - It's good to have skillful hands - Good work!How did the Soviet Union justify paying different wages to different workers? Are not people all equal in the work place? The USSR justified different wages with different levels of education and qualifications of the employee. Every person is different and there are absolutely no identical people. But according to similar parameters, it was just the qualification guide for the professions. Work in the USSR corresponded to special rules and norms. There were certain special departments and people who checked for example how much time work is possible. These people were called normalizers (normirovschik). That is, people who determine the norm by the production of an employee for a certain time.  ЕТКС Issue 1 Unified tariff-qualification reference book of works and occupations of workers.There was a ЕТКС Issue 1 Unified tariff-qualification reference book of works and occupations of workers (tarifikator). There were labor standards. To increase wages, also confirmed experience and education. For example a worker if he graduated from a higher education institution and could work as an engineer but while working as a worker - he received an increase in rank or leadership position and a salary increase.  udarnik kommunisticheskogo trudaThere was both an best worker (peredovik proizvodstva) and a Communist of Labor (udarnik kommunisticheskogo truda), that is, people working better and producing more and better products. Such people had benefits and increased pay.  Poster is a joke: Even the most superstitious person will not give up his 13 salary. That is from receiving not 12 salaries a year but 13.For employees, the general conditions were initially offered - what they described as equalization (uravnilovka). But then if the worker worked well, he had a large salary and received bonuses in the form of additional sums of money. Also at the enterprises there was a so-called 13 salary that when at the end of the year the employee received or two and three salaries.  Poster of the USSR: Conscientious work for the benefit of society - who does not work does not eat!If the employee went out to work at night, he received a special increase for work at night. The same rule was for a weekend or a holiday.  Poster of the USSR on labor - If did a poor job, then and earned a wery littleThe employee sometimes received a salary - this is a fixed wage (oklad). But there were also bonuses and 13 salaries. Or the worker was paid by piecework. That is, the minimum salary and payment depends on the number of products produced. According to the rate of payment for one piece of products. Quality of products was controlled by a special department of the OTK (technical control department), it monitored the production technology and the absence of violations. The employee was obliged to observe safety rules at work. He was instructed by a special inspector for the protection of labor safety.  Certificate of early release of the prisoner Dmitrovlag for shock work on the construction of the Moscow-Volga Channel. The prisoner. To 13 years in prison. He was convicted in 1936. For good work he was released in 1937!By the way, speaking of the Gulag, first of all, this is the system of execution of punishments and it exists in any country. So, working in a terrible Gulag, the worker received wages for his work. For example, the repressed father of Yeltsin quotes the following: his familiar repressed doctor, for example, received a salary corresponding to the chief engineer in ordinary production and even sent money from his prison (Gulag) to his family. Prisoners of Gulag also participated in sports parades on the red square. Prisoners played in amateur performances and theaters. In some camps there were even amateur of aviation where the prisoner received the profession of a pilot. Is not it strange for the Gulag? Everything is in the documents. The norms for payment and labor protection of prisoners in GULAG (ITL - Ispravitelniy Trudvoy Lager - corrective labor camp) were established by the OGPU - NKVD - MVD in agreement with the People's Commissariat of Labor of the USSR, and in the ITC of the RSFSR in 1933 (Article 72) the standards of payment for persons deprived of their liberty were determined by a special instruction of the NKJ of the RSFSR and the AUCCTU. The conditions of labor were regulated by the general rules of the Labor Code of the RSFSR When I read Solzhenitsyn in 1980. Why my grandmother and my grandfather and even people who were repressed during Stalin's time speak well of him? I began to collect documents about the Gulag, but I was very surprised that Solzhenitsyn was not right. I was in the camps of the Gulag, in the camps of Hitler and when I was in the USA I even looked at the documents about the labor camps of the USA. It's true a lot of interesting. Unfortunately, politicians and the media sometimes say not at all. I do not justify labor camps.  Poster of the USSR poster for prisoners - Honest work and exemplary behavior will speed up your freedomIf we talk about senior Soviet officials, they had salaries and everything depended on the ministry. Each ministry and its units had their own scores for the work.  The map of the USSR - gray-blue colo is northern territories and as a rule it is the northern coefficient, that is, the salary is twice as largeAs an employee, if he worked in Siberia, his work was indexed by the so-called Northern coefficient (severnie) and he received more nearly three or four times than for example an employee of the same profession in Moscow.  Make yourself eat black caviar!If we talk about the military, the role was played by the title and position. That is, for the post the military received a salary and received additionally for the title or as the military said - for the asterisks (the asterisks were on the shoulder straps of the leading military commanders of the USSR). Just for the military, there were certain additions to the salary due to the location of the military service. The military in the USSR was almost entirely on state security - he did not pay for food, housing, clothes, rest - everything was provided by the state. The profession of the military was prestigious and well-paid. If the military retired into the reserve or simply decided to move to a non-military position and withdraw from the Ministry of Defense, the military received many additional benefits. The USSR paid him a year's wages while he was looking for a job. To provide housing in the area that he chose to live. Helped family when moving. The Military Academy in the transition to a peaceful profession was equal to the Academy or the University. But in any case, when applying for work, everything was checked by the personnel department commission. The main thing - in the USSR there was no unemployment and there was no stress from the possible loss of work. A good specialist received a good salary. If a person took a loan from a bank, then he did not pay interest, but simply paid the amount that he took.

Because there was a country-wide pay grade system. Salary was dependent on the job not on the person doing the job. Jobs that required more physical effort, knowledge and jobs carrying more responsibility were compensated higher. For example our neighbour, a simple worker, was paid more than my parents, university professors, because he was working in a health hazardous job at a plant. He has liver cirrhosis now but technically he got paid for it upfront. Also, compensation was dependent on location. The whole country was divided into regions according to the harshness of living conditions. Even when buying any packaged goods in a store, one could see three different price categories for Central regions, Siberia and Far East. There was some degree of differentiation between people in the same pay grade doing the same job that was dependent on their seniority. All of that as you can imagine reduced productivity since there was no competition. There were lousy attempts to increase productivity through competition. The most common among them was to reward teams with the highest productivity with a red flag :) and some praising and monetary bonuses. As to the ideological justification, the reason given for pay differentiation was the fact that the Communism had not been built in Soviet Union yet. According to the Communist doctrine, there would be no money at all in the Communist society. Every member of the society would give as much as they can to it and get as much as they need. As we all know that point was never reached. I find it hard to believe cz what if I want to work 2 hour a day and go sailing for the rest. Potentially with high degree of robotization mankind could come to it. There are already some regions around the globe playing around with a universal income. The idea is that people don't need to work at all like in the industrial era but rather do only creative tasks to their liking.

The equal payment thinking was widespread in the USSR, but for a totally different reason. We had a disparaging word uravnílovka for it. It existed because most often the Soviet principles of management were so funny that even the most intransigent perfectionists would give up and just share the pay equally among all who claimed to be around. However, the Soviet system had very meritocratic aspirations. Those who contributed more to the triumph of Communism were entitled to more than others. It would be only fair, would it not? To come out of the impasse, the USSR established a system that reminded of the Estates of the realm in the Middle ages. You needed to build a personal record of good work. If you were a Gulag inmate, an immaculate work would expedite your upgrade to the estate of free people. If you were a mere peasant or worker, a Stakhanovite effort would give you an upgrade to some clean daytime office job. Jumping higher into some low-level managerial chair would mean a better pay, plus a set list of perks, like faster advancement in the waiting line for a larger residential room, a month of free stay at some summer resort at the Black Sea. And so forth. My main aspiration in my time in propaganda was joining the honorable ranks of Nomenklatura. Among their perks was the access to most of the Western press, foreign trips without a written approval from KGB for each of them, the access to a canteen in the Proyezd Vladimirova where I could eat restaurant-quality meals at the prices of a street-corner stand in Mumbai, and much-much else. There were experiments during the early years of Brezhnev rule and under Gorbachev to motivate people by paying more to those who worked more productively. But these were widely sabotaged by bureaucrats. Most importantly, with the persistent scarcity of goods and services, there wasn’t much to spend these money on, anyways. The poster below from 1964 is a rare Soviet piece of propaganda showing the monetary advantages of a good work: “Good work makes good salary”. Elsewhere, it was “blossoming” and “development” of our Soviet Motherland that was normally extolled as the most worthy remuneration for the best effort.

Honestly, I’m enthusiastic about Dan Holliday’s proposal to release a compilation of Dima Vorobiev replies. I even came up with the name for this collection. Something like this, Propaganda for Dummies or how to crap your former homeland to deserve the praise of her enemies, but the fools would think it was a praise to the glory of her. In Russian it sounds better (Пропаганда для чайников или как правильно обосрать свою бывшую родину, чтобы заслужить похвалу ее врагов, а дураки чтобы думали, что ты ее похвалил) but, alas, English is not my mother tongue. The title question borders with infantilism. There is no such a thing in nature like people all equal in the work-place. The work of a welder performing an overhead bead on the 300-meter elevation (welder of highest category #6) does not resemble the work of a welder, working inside a workshop performing a weld in the flat position (welder of lower category #2). Ah, I guess you don't know a thing about such stuff like elevations and welding bead positions, eh? Never mind this was only an example hoping to give you a sense of the extent to which one has to stoop to represent the Soviet system as entirely chaotic to disgust shithole of idiotic dogma and senseless rules. In the picture below you may see the document which I used when at the end of each month filled out the payroll for the team of steeplejacks on one of the construction sites. Such or similar price lists (or catalogs) were in use in each sector of the national economy. Ah, yes in a way your questions does make sense. Say all professors get more or less equal salaries, the wages of welders of rank #6 also were equal more or less; the wages of the office plankton in the propaganda department was not much different from that in the office of the Gosplan. Truck driver on long distances earned more than a novice officer in the state insurance company or propaganda department. Of course, clerks (some of them) were offended, who need the fucking revolution if a redneck earns more than we do.  The title (to the right) reads: Unified standards and rates for construction, installation and repair work. issue 22 welding work.

According to the Soviet ( Bolshevik’s ) doctrina, the only legal Employer in USSR could be the state, the only owner of capital goods. As a result there was no real job market, i.e. there was no way to look for better compensation, the salaries for almost all positions were dictated by the state authorities. However, there were some legal options to differ the wages, for example - prizes for most productive ( shouldn’t I write “loyal” here? ) employees, extra payments fictional overtime, or for work in fields or in distant areas, some benefits were coming from the so-called “social funds” ( e.g. an option to wave transportation, housing, and medical service expenses during the vacation time ). Beside there were some professional association ( e.g. writers, composers, etc ), as well as some licensed enterprises ( e.g. tailors, tinkers, etc ). Of course there were some clandestine production nets, where the state-owned equipment and raw materials were used for illegal business activity and producing hidden or not taxable income.

Because communist theory does not preclude paying people based on their performance and contribution. Many get confused by the “from each according to his means, to each according to his needs” bit, and think that means everybody got (or was supposed to get) the same. However, that applies only to the final stage of communism - a utopia when the state will wither away, and mankind would have been transformed into altruistic idealists, not driven by crass materialism. That was for down the road - an aspiration and an end goal. In the meantime, while communist governments (named after where they want to end up, not what they actually are) were striving to get there, they had to deal with their citizens as they were at present, not as if they were the citizens of the future utopia who don’t care about material rewards. Ergo, you incentivize them the usual way, by paying them based on performance and contribution.
